Present:
The Right Hon. Neville Chamberlain, MP, Prime Minister (in the Chair).
The Right Hon. Sir John Simon, K.C, M.P, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

General von Fritsch, who was reported killed in action in Poland, had been the most likely rallying point for an army movement against the Nazi regime. It seemed unlikely that he would have been killed in action and he might therefore have been " liquidated."
The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs drew attention to Telegram No. 536 of the 23rd September from His Majesty's Ambassador at Washington. 4. The Deputy Chief of the Imperial General Staff said that the movement of the Field Force to France was proceeding without incident. The movement of our troops to the forward area had started; they would proceed thence to their front line positions as soon as possible.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.

Staff Conversations with Belgium.
(Previous Reference: W.M. (39) 24th Conclusions, Minute 11.)
5. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs informed the War Cabinet that he had seen the Belgian Ambassador on the previous evening, and had put to him, as clearly and as fully as possible, the arguments in favour of the holding of Staff Conversations between ourselves and the Belgians.
The Belgian Ambassador, while appreciating our point of view, made it quite clear that it would be out of the question for the Belgian Government to agree to our suggestion. They were satisfied that Germany did not intend to violate their neutrality, but feared that the news of Staff Conversations, which would be sure to reach German ears, would precipitate an attack.
The Belgian Ambassador had thought it possible that his Government might reconsider their attitude if the Germans concentrated strong forces on their frontier. He was most unwilling, however, to approach his Government on the subject at the present time. The results of the interview had therefore been entirely negative.
The Belgian Government's attitude was likely to be hardened as a result of Dr. Goebbels's statement (see Telegram No. 112, Saving, from Brussels), that Germany had no intention of violating the neutrality of Belgium or Holland.
The War Cabinet took note of this statement.

The Far Eastern Situation.
British Gunboats in China.
(Previous 'Reference: W.M. (39) 24th Conclusions, Minute 7.)
7. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs referred to an intelligence report that the Japanese were obstructing the movement of stores to our river gunboats on the Yangtse. He understood that three of the vessels had stores for three months and the remaining two for one month only. From the purely political point of view, it was desirable that the gunboats should remain on the Yangtse at the moment. If, however, the Admiralty foresaw any danger of a serious incident, the Foreign Office would take the view that it would be better to withdraw the gunboats.
The Deputy Chief of Naval Staff said that the Commander-in-Chief, China Station, had been told on the previous day that it was politically undesirable to withdraw the gunboats at the moment. The Admiralty were satisfied, however, that the Commander-in-Chief would feel at liberty, in the light of the orders already given to him, to withdraw any of the gunboats if he considered that the situation demanded it.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.

Ambassador, showed that negotiations were still proceeding on a (Previous number of points of detail and that no immediate action was called Reference: for.
W.M. (39) 24th The chancellor of the Exchequer thought that the statement Conclusions, -m paragraph 5; as to the initialling and signature of the Treaty, was distinctly more hopeful. As regards the points still unsettled, the important question was not whether the rate of interest should be 3 or 4 per cent., but whether we should undertake to provide Turkey with gold in London, or to hand over bullion at Istanbul. He much preferred the former course, since we could then exercise some control over the way in which Turkey used the gold. In this connection the Chancellor enquired what the position was in regard to the Polish bullion which was now in transit to Marseilles via Beirut.
The War Cabinet took note of these statements.
Propaganda In Germany.
Export of capital by certain Nazi Leaders.
9. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs drew attention to a telegram received from His Majesty's Minister at Copenhagen, urging tJhat frequent reference should be made in our German broadcasts to the large investments placed abroad by certain Nazi Leaders.
The Prime Minister thought that, owing to restrictions on receiving sets in Germany, our propaganda on this matter should be done by leaflets. It had long been notorious in Germany that these leaders had lived in luxury, and enjoyed privileges and immunities denied to the ordinary citizen. When it became generally known in Germany that these leaders had also broken their own very drastic laws against the export of capital, there would be a very strong revulsion of feeling, from which they might never recover. It was to the credit of Herr Hitler that his name had never been associated with these scandals.
Reference was made to a report that certain bags of coffee, consigned to Herr Hitler, had been seized and were now before the Prize Court. Discussion ensued as to whether, if the hearing of this case could be expedited, valuable propaganda material could not be obtained from it, in view of the scarcity of coffee in Germany. Varying views were expressed on this point.
The War Cabinet agreed :
that the attention of the Minister of Information should be drawn to the telegram from Copenhagen referred to above, and also to the Prime Minister's suggestion that propaganda on this matter should be carried out by leaflets.
Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1, September 24, 1939.
